title: Old Mortality, Volume 1.
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: "Being the youngest son of a numerous family, he, at an early age,     went to serve with an elder brother, named Francis, who rented, from     Sir John Jardine of Applegarth, a small tract in Comcockle Moor,     near Lochmaben.

title: The Abbot
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: It rolled away like mist before thesun, and he was easily engaged in a keen and animated dissertation aboutLochleven trout, and sea trout, and river trout, and bull trout, andchar, which never rise to a fly, and par, which some suppose infantsalmon, and _herlings_, which frequent the Nith, and _vendisses_, whichare only found in the Castle-Loch of Lochmaben; and he was hurrying onwith the eager impetuosity and enthusiasm of a young sportsman, when heobserved that the smile with which the Queen at first listened to himdied languidly away, and that, in spite of her efforts to suppress them,tears rose to her eyes.

title: Song and scenery;

title: Song and scenery;
author: Moffat, James C.
snippet: Tying the halter of the Warden's finest charger round her neck, he let them out, and, having seen them fairly on the road to Lochmaben, returned to his harp.

title: Song and scenery;
author: Moffat, James C.
snippet: There has been poetry about Lochmaben, as must be about the birthplace of the liberator king ; but I am sorry to say that the people thereabouts evince little sense of it.

title: Song and scenery;
author: Moffat, James C.
snippet: The old castle of the Bruces at Lochmaben was planted in the midst of its best.

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr. Alexander Carlyle, Minister of Inveresk,
author: Carlyle, Alexander
snippet: And havino- had the manao-ement of the burgh of Lochmaben for Charles Erskine of Tinwald  at twenty-nine years of age, he acquired early that address and dexterity in managing men which could easily be applied to Edinburgh politics, though they were on a much greater scale.

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr. Alexander Carlyle, Minister of Inveresk,
author: Carlyle, Alexander
snippet: The calling of the roll began, and when it had passed the presbytery of Lochmaben, he gave a significant look with his eye to me, who was sitting below the throne, as much as to say, " Now the day's our own."

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr. Alexander Carlyle, Minister of Inveresk,
author: Carlyle, Alexander
snippet: Before we parted, Jardine told me that he had examined the list of the Assembly with care, and that we should carry the question — that it would be nearly at par till we came as far on the roll as Lochmaben, but that after that we should have it hollow.

snippet: from Captain Lindsay when we came to Longtown, for lie went to Lochmaben, and we took the road to Dumfries, where, after staying a few days, I took the road home by Moffat, and Wight went over to Ire- laud, once more to visit his friends there.

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr. Alexander Carlyle, Minister of Inveresk,
author: Carlyle, Alexander
snippet: As I designed to convey Wight to Dumfries, and Captain Lindsay was going by Lochmaben to visit his brother James, tlie minister, we agreed to set out together, and made a very agreeable journey.

snippet: The ground of his patriotism was thus unveiled, and he was no longer of any consequence, though he thought he could sway the burgh of Lochmaben,  where he was minister at that time.

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr Alexander Carlyle ;

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr Alexander Carlyle ;

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr Alexander Carlyle ;
author: Carlyle, Alexander
snippet: After a long grace said by Mr Jardine for it was his turn now, being the third brandy-bottle we had seen since we left Lochmaben she emptied it to our healths, and made the gentlemen follow her example : she said she would spare me as I was so young, but ordered a maid to bring a gingerbread cake from the cupboard, a luncheon of which she put in my pocket.

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr Alexander Carlyle ;
author: Carlyle, Alexander
snippet: At this time, too, I made a very agreeable tour round the country with my father and Mr Robert Jardine [minister of Lochmaben],the father of Dr Jardine, afterwards  minister of Edinburgh.

title: Jane Seton: or, the Kings Advocate. A Scottish historical romance
author: Grant, James
snippet: " His reserve?" said the earl, scornfuUy ; " and thushe vents his petulance on a gallant knight, as he wouldupon his pimps of the house of Arran—those rascallyHamiltons," he added, with eyes flashing fire, " who,gorged to theh full with the plunder of our kinsmen,are budding unto themselves strengths from which evenour valour can never drive them—castles and towers,to wliich the palaces of Lochmaben and Linhthgow arebut huts and shedings."

title: Jane Seton: or, the Kings Advocate. A Scottish historical romance
author: Grant, James
snippet: " His reserve?" said the earl, scornfuUy ; " and thushe vents his petulance on a gallant knight, as he wouldupon his pimps of the house of Arran—those rascallyHamiltons," he added, with eyes flashing fire, " who,gorged to theh full with the plunder of our kinsmen,are budding unto themselves strengths from which evenour valour can never drive them—castles and towers,to which the palaces of Lochmaben and Linhthgow arebut huts and shedings."
